author: ralexstokes
content: so imo the syntax is dense and a bit confusing here

author: ralexstokes
content: every account can have a "storage root" (or hash), which is a commitment to a particular account's storage (if they have it)

author: ralexstokes
content: you can only write to storage w/ `SSTORE` so if this storage root is non-empty, it also implies there is bytecode attached to this account, aka it is a "smart contract"

author: ralexstokes
content: all that bit of the yellow paper is saying is: to compute the storage hash, you want to take every key that exists ("storage slot") along with its associated value, which is an RLP-encoded thing

author: ralexstokes
content: you hash the key and the pair `(KEC(k), RLP(v))` is one input to the trie

author: ralexstokes
content: you compute these pairs for all storage slots that have been written to and then use them as inputs to the merkle patricia-trie we use for the ethereum state

author: ralexstokes
content: so that if you look up the key `KEC(k)` in the trie, you will get back `RLP(v)`

author: ralexstokes
content: the root of this trie is `œÉ[a]_s`

author: ralexstokes
content: `sigma` is the "world state", the global state that can be derived by starting from the genesis state of ethereum and executing every transaction, the "index" of `a` refers to a particular account in this state, like you have an account with an address, the `a` is the address and it acts as an index into the top-level "world state", so every `sigma[a]` is an account and those accounts that are "smart contracts" may have a non-empty storage hash (the root hash of the MP trie used to encode storage keys/values), the subscript `s` is used to single out the storage hash, as opposed to the nonce or balance or code hash, i forget which subscripts are used to get these other properties of a single account
